text: My name is Amy Burge and I'm a teaching fellow in the School of Literatures,
Languages and Cultures and I also work in the Institute for Academic Development
in the group of people who support tutors and demonstrators. I teach people how to
teach effectively. There are a few key values that drive my teaching. I think one
of the most important is thinking about the student as an active learner. So I
like to focus much more on what the student does and less on what I do. This is
perhaps more in the classroom scenario because of course in advance when I'm
preparing for teaching I am doing quite a lot of things but the things I do are
mainly in order so that in the classroom itself it's I'm doing less I'm talking
less and the students are doing more. So to promote student learning in my
teaching I very much think about students as I said as active learners and I
like to think about the teaching environment a little bit differently because I
think trying to break down that classroom space where students are sitting
and facing you is really important in getting them to do something active. So
for example in a course I organise where I teach research research methods I
like to use the workshop space and get students to do something active whether
that be group discussion whether that be working creatively to cut and stick
some documents together whether that be doing some writing together I like to
try and think about ways students can learn through doing rather than just
thinking and this can be a simple discussion occasionally if I think students
puzzling over something over a concept or an idea I might break it down for
five minute discussion and then come back and then carry on my lecture or carry
on my discussion drawing on what students have been saying and I think that makes
it a much more two way kind of process of teaching. In lectures where you have
say 200 students in a room I've used post-it notes quite effectively I did
then have to go through 400 post-it notes after the lecture but in the session
itself students really seemed to appreciate that and that was a way to get
students doing something actively when you're in a large scenario where that
might feel more difficult. So ways that I engage students in being active and
in trying new things I like to offer students a variety of learning tasks and
learning activities so for example in a typical session I might spend a few
minutes introducing things then I might ask students to do a discussion activity
and then I would move to trying something different I very much think that
students learn in different ways and so I like to offer a range of different
things that allow each student a chance to perhaps engage so some students
might prefer discussion some students might prefer writing some students might
prefer just some quite time to think about stuff so I'd like to kind of offer a
variety and engaging students I like to think I make my class from quite an
inclusive place so I would perhaps mix groups up if there's a group where there
are some particularly quiet people and try and make sure that everyone feels
included but in a non-threatening way as much as possible so I don't like to
call students out and say you haven't added anything what do you think I
like to it's almost having a bad day I wouldn't necessarily want to call them
out on it and make their day worse but I like to think my classroom is
supportive in a kind of caring nurturing way but one that's still rigorous. I
think my teaching values and practices have changed a lot in the five five or
six years I've been teaching at a university level I started being quite
nervous and thinking quite a lot about how I needed to fill the time and myself
as the holder of all knowledge and students would test me and if I didn't know
the right answer to a question it would be the worst thing that could ever
happen I'd spend hours preparing classes and thinking very much about what I
needed to do to fill the time I didn't really think about the students at all
and that as I've become more confident and got to know my material better I've
thought a bit more about what the students are doing and I think my exposure to
different ways of teaching observing other people teaching and also working in
the IED and my role supporting tutors and demonstrators it's exposed me to
lots of new ways of thinking some of it informed by education theory and that
very much has made me think more about what students do in the classroom which
has also helped to make me feel less nervous about what I'm doing because if
I'm not thinking about what I'm doing if I'm getting students to do stuff
then the pressures of me it's on the students to engage and to do things so I
think my my values in general in terms of students being active and learning in
an active way hasn't necessarily shifted but it's become more clearly defined
more clearly articulated and I think my practices have become much more
obvious in reflecting that so changing the way I've structured my courses
changing the kinds of environments I try and teach in so taking students out
with the classroom trying to find rooms where I can move the tables around
and group students in small groups rather than having them all facing a
particular direction I've become more purposeful in doing that because it's
much more aligned now with a kind of clearer articulation of my values
